dt: {bc}to postpone {d_link|induction|induction} of (a person) into military service

pt: {sc}defer{/sc} {sc}postpone{/sc} {sc}suspend{/sc} {sc}stay{/sc} mean to delay an action or proceeding. {sc}defer{/sc} implies a deliberate putting off to a later time.
{sc}postpone{/sc} implies an intentional deferring usually to a definite time.
{sc}suspend{/sc} implies temporary stoppage with an added suggestion of waiting until some condition is satisfied.

pt.t: business will be {it}suspended{/it} while repairs are underway

pt: {sc}stay{/sc} often suggests the stopping or checking by an intervening agency or authority.

quotes.t: Backers say the arrangement will make patients more cost-conscious and judicious in their use of medical service, thus restraining health-cost increases; critics say it will cause patients to {qword}defer{/qword} needed treatment and will be attractive only to younger, healthier workers.

A far stronger signal came when the draft was revived, shortly before the United States entered World War II. Although married men with families were eligible for induction, in many cases up to the age of forty, high school students were automatically {qword}deferred{/qword}.
The decision was {qword}deferred{/qword} for a time. John didn't want to do anything drastic until after October …

et: Middle English {it}differren, deferren,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}differer,{/it} borrowed (with conjugational change) from Latin {it}differre{/it} "to carry away in varying directions, spread abroad, postpone, delay, be unlike or distinct" {ma}{mat|differ|}{/ma}

The verb {it}defer{/it} is not distinct etymologically from {et_link|differ|differ}—see note at etymology of that entry. The spelling of the initial unstressed syllable as {it}-e-{/it} was perhaps by association with {et_link|delay:2|delay:2}.
shortdef: to postpone induction of (a person) into military service

dt.t: he could {wi}defer{/wi} his job to no one

dt: {bc}to submit to another's wishes, opinion, or governance usually through {a_link|deference} or respect

pt: {sc}yield{/sc} {sc}submit{/sc} {sc}capitulate{/sc} {sc}succumb{/sc} {sc}relent{/sc} {sc}defer{/sc} mean to give way to someone or something that one can no longer resist. {sc}yield{/sc} may apply to any sort or degree of giving way before force, argument, persuasion, or entreaty.
{sc}submit{/sc} suggests full surrendering after resistance or conflict to the will or control of another.

pt.t: a repentant sinner vowing to {it}submit{/it} to the will of God

pt: {sc}capitulate{/sc} stresses the fact of ending all resistance and may imply either a coming to terms (as with an adversary) or hopelessness in the face of an irresistible opposing force.
{sc}succumb{/sc} implies weakness and helplessness to the one that gives way or an overwhelming power to the opposing force.

pt.t: a stage actor {it}succumbing{/it} to the lure of Hollywood

pt: {sc}relent{/sc} implies a yielding through pity or mercy by one who holds the upper hand.

pt.t: finally {it}relented{/it} and let the children stay up late

pt: {sc}defer{/sc} implies a voluntary yielding or submitting out of respect or reverence for or deference and affection toward another.

pt.t: I {it}defer{/it} to your expertise in these matters

quotes.t: But in 1775, when William chose loyalty to empire over deference to his father, Franklin abruptly, angrily, and permanently broke with his son. Despite having defied his own father (in leaving Boston), Franklin pulled patriarchal rank to demand that his son {qword}defer{/qword} to his politics: "there are natural duties which precede political ones, and cannot be extinguished by them."
Israelis can be harsh with each other, but they {qword}defer{/qword} to the security guards who check their backpacks at the mall entrances. They put their faith in the Army.

et: Middle English {it}differen, deferen{/it} "to submit (a matter) for decision, submit to another's judgment," borrowed from Middle French {it}deferer, deferrer{/it} "to bring (a defendant) before a court, submit to another's will," borrowed (with conjugation change) from Medieval Latin {it}dēferre{/it} "to convey, show respect, submit to a decision" (Late Latin, "to pay respect to"), going back to Latin, "to bring down, convey, transfer, submit," from {it}dē-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} + {it}ferre{/it} "to carry, convey" {ma}{mat|bear:2|}{/ma}
shortdef: to submit to another's wishes, opinion, or governance usually through deference or respect

dt: {bc}to allow (someone else) to decide or choose something

dt.t: You have more experience with this, so I'm going to {it}defer to{/it} you.

dt: {bc}to agree to follow (someone else's decision, a tradition, etc.)

dt.t: The court {it}defers to{/it} precedent in cases like these.

shortdef: to allow (someone else) to decide or choose something
to agree to follow (someone else's decision, a tradition, etc.)
